section.title: will and would
section.sectiontitle: We use if + Present simple + will/won't + verb to talk about real possibilities in the future.
section.text1: It's very possible that the weather will be good tomorrow.
section.text1a: If the weather stays good tomorrow, we'll go to the beach.
section.text2: It's also possible that it will rain.
section.text2a: If it rains, we won't go for a picnic.
section.sectiontitle2: We use if + Past simple + would/wouldn't + verb to talk about imaginary situations.
section.text3: It's very unlikely that I'll win the lottery.
section.text3a: If I won the lottery, I'd travel around the world.

section.title: will and would
section.sectiontitle: The choice of will or would sometimes depends on how we see a situation.
section.text1: The speaker thinks it's a real possibility that he'll get the job.
section.text1a: If I get the job, we'll go out to celebrate.
section.text2: The speaker doesn't think he'll get the job. He's imagining it.
section.text2a: If I got the job, I'd make a lot of changes.
